review: I met this author when he visited Toronto a few years ago and wanted to like this one more. I struggled to keep focused, keep track of the characters,I met this author when he visited Toronto a few years ago and wanted to like this one more. I struggled to keep focused, keep track of the characters, the dialogue and where the story was going. I did like the characters, especially Nicky and Sebastian and appreciated the book references but it was a bit 'all over the place' and probably could have been edited to more the length of an Agatha Christie mystery. I figured out a big part of the plot at 40% so it took my 5 days to get back to reading through to the end to figure out the rest.I did learn a new word: uxorcide; and liked this quote: "we're all in that story. life is a thriller. the ending is fatal and the conclusion is final"...more

title: Followed by the Lark
author: Humphreys, Helen
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Helen Humphreys does not disappoint in her melodic snippets, sharing the life of Henry David Thoreau and his appreciation of the natural world. She shHelen Humphreys does not disappoint in her melodic snippets, sharing the life of Henry David Thoreau and his appreciation of the natural world. She shares bits of his life in a seasonal rhythm noting the changes in the trees, the ponds and as the birds migrate and return for spring.It is reflective and notes all of the loss his family suffered - his sister, brother (a dreadful death from lockjaw after cutting himself sharpening his shaving blade), father (TB) and his own death at 44 years of age from consumption (TB). He appreciated his walks, camping trips and floats down the river while life slowly left him until he could travel no more and died listening to his remaining sister tell the story of his float down the river with his beloved brother, John, who had died at the age of 22.Followed by the Lark makes me want to learn more about Henry Thoreau, his sojourn beside Walden Pond and his connections with Ralph Waldo Emerson, Bronson (the father of Louisa May Alcott) and Walt Whitman. It makes me reflect on the challenges of a time before curative medicine and before life got so busy that many don't take time to appreciate the nature around us....more

title: The Perfect Story: How to Tell Stories that Inform, Influence, and Inspire
author: Eber, Karen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Someday... I would love to give a TED talk. I love the energy, the stories and how these tales stay alive online. Karen Ever shares her tips on how toSomeday... I would love to give a TED talk. I love the energy, the stories and how these tales stay alive online. Karen Ever shares her tips on how to tell these stories. She provides checklists and links the tips to her own stories.As an avid reader, her book makes me think about what creates connection and resonates as I read or listen and I am left with the idea of telling the story that the audience wants to here which may be different than the story a person wishes to tell. The other thing that resonates is how much time and effort goes into preparation while the viewer/listener just sees the end result (which, surprise, is edited!).A great book of tips and examples... my only constructive criticism (for the publishers) is that the book has terrible paper... thin pages that are more like newsprint and seem to stick together....more

title: The Phoenix Crown
author: Quinn, Kate*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Phoenix Crown was the perfect historical fiction - engaging characters blended with true history, making a reader want to research more about the The Phoenix Crown was the perfect historical fiction - engaging characters blended with true history, making a reader want to research more about the San Francisco earth quake, the fires that followed and, of course. what exactly was a phoenix crown.This collaboration between the fabulous Kate Quinn and Janie Chang led to a plot twisting book that was hard to put down despite the late hour. The reader appreciated the strength and resilience of the strong female characters who had to support each other in their quest for justice.I was lucky to have attended a tea at the Arlington in Paris, Ontario to meet both authors. Had I finished the book in advance, I wish that I could have told them that they are 15 minutes from an Octagonal House in Mount Pleasant and was interested to learn how few of them (80) remain in the US today.I loved the author's notes at the end, expounding on the characters, both imaginary and historical as well as notes about the setting and history. It was so interesting to learn that Kate Quinn had financed her university as a soprano singing opera!...more

review: Watching iCarly with the kids, I had no idea of the trauma and abuse that Jennette McCurdy (Sam) was living. On the show, she was tough and loveable bWatching iCarly with the kids, I had no idea of the trauma and abuse that Jennette McCurdy (Sam) was living. On the show, she was tough and loveable but in life, she was mentally and physically abused by her mother who showered her until she was in her late teens, who taught her to be anorexic and pushed her into a life of show business to meet her own needs. The title has been shared as a “joke” but truly, it was not until her mother died that healing began. Such a sad expose on a child star and reinforces that we never know what others are going through. ...more

title: Fourteen Days: An Unauthorized Gathering
author: Atwood, Margaret*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Fourteen Days is an interesting compilation of stories told on an apartment rooftop in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic. While Margaret Atwood contrFourteen Days is an interesting compilation of stories told on an apartment rooftop in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic. While Margaret Atwood contributed, she also edited the stories into the book Fourteen Days. Notable Canadian and American authors included: John Grisham, Emma Donahue, Tommy Orange, R.L. Stone, Celeste Ng, Diana Gabaldon and a myriad of other authors totalling 36 contributions.A ragtag group of individuals met on the roof, banged pots to celebrate health care providers and became a community while they alternated telling stories.Not to share a spoiler, all I will say is that the ending brought things together for me. I appreciated this collaborative fiction for its' unique voice and coming together of so many authors. Some of the stories left me puzzling and if I didn't have a mass of other books to read, I would be curious to go back and reread in the frame of which authors contributed each story. I probably would have rated. 3.5 if this was a goodreads possibility and appreciate the unique voices in the story of a pandemic....more

review: I enjoyed this book and would have liked to give it a 3.5. It is fan fiction yet entwined a serious topic of cultural appropriation. It is a quick reaI enjoyed this book and would have liked to give it a 3.5. It is fan fiction yet entwined a serious topic of cultural appropriation. It is a quick read, a fast moving story with a tension created by wanting to like Junie while knowing she did something terribly wrong. It addresses the horrible culture of social media with snippets of twitter (now renamed) and attacks that go viral. It leaves a reader reflecting on the ethics of writing and who should be telling stories. It will be a fun book club discussion for February! ...more

title: Meet Me at the Lake
author: Fortune, Carley*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If it wasn't for the notes at the end, I probably would have given this book a 2. If I could give half stars, I would have given it a 2.5 but am roundIf it wasn't for the notes at the end, I probably would have given this book a 2. If I could give half stars, I would have given it a 2.5 but am rounding it up to a 3. This was my last of the 5 short-listed books and I should note that I LOVE that Canada Reads introduces books that I might not normally read and books that others enjoy. it is wonderful to be introduced to a variety of new authors, writing styles and genres. Although romance is not my favourite, I am looking forward to the discussion.As for this book, I couldn't help but roll my eyes at some of the descriptions, Stephen King in his book On Writing would definitely be cringing (perhaps that is not the point and I should have just got into the flow of the beach type read and suspended my critical eye...) but really??? here are some examples:"how dark his eyes are, black as a crows wing"or"the air tasted of vending machine sandwiches, diesel fumes and misery".... what??or"she had a round face with hazel doe eyes and a tiny cherry of a nose that under most circumstances made her seem deceptively innocent"or "bottom lashes were an exaggerated curve, as black as the lake at midnight"In the end, the story made me think of friends who do own and live on a resort in Huntsville. the setting seemed idyllic. I think I might have liked the story if the writers notes at the end, were more incorporated into the story, dealing with more of the serious issues on PPD and anxiety.I am looking forward to the debates... I know that the best book does not always win but the defenders are always interesting and it always gets more Canadians interested in reading!!Let the games begin!!!...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This series of linked short stories was gritty and raw. It is sad to think about the struggles of teens and young g adults as they live in public housThis series of linked short stories was gritty and raw. It is sad to think about the struggles of teens and young g adults as they live in public housing and try to fit in. It causes readers to reflect on what others have dealt with, struggle through and overcome. It highlights that throughout the challenges, there is resilience and a capacity to move forward despite hardships. As an adult, it is hard to think of youth dealing with these adult issues and this should lead to interesting discussions on Canada reads. ...more

title: Denison Avenue
author: Wong, Christina
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am thankful that this book was flagged to me by the Canada Reads long-list and wish that I had read it in a paper version so appreciate the beautifuI am thankful that this book was flagged to me by the Canada Reads long-list and wish that I had read it in a paper version so appreciate the beautiful drawings more. It is a poignant tale of seniors living in their neighbourhood (Chinatown) as it changes. It is about love, loss, kindness, grief, comfort and every day coping. It is beautifully written and a book that I would like a hard copy to re-read, slowly, to take in the dialogue (written often in both Cantonese and English), the memories and think about the areas depicted in the art. This book would make very interesting discussion as we often don't think about seniors, their lives, their memories and what they have to offer as well as the changes in community and the impacts on the long-term residents. This book is reflective, thought-provoking and will stay with me....more

title: Study for Obedience
author: Bernstein, Sarah
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Perhaps the timing to read this book was not right for this Giller prize-winning novel… I struggled to stay focussed with the stream on consciousness Perhaps the timing to read this book was not right for this Giller prize-winning novel… I struggled to stay focussed with the stream on consciousness style of writing. The writing, itself, was lovely but I am still puzzling with the slow-paced story of an unnamed sister who goes to an unnamed place to live with her unnamed brother. It reads like past days of witch trials in some ways yet speaks to using the internet and cell phones. It is unique and well-written but not my cup of tea and was glad it was short in its’ oddness. ...more
